question: # Q1. If you want to import just the Component from the React library, what syntax do you use?
# Q2. If a function component should always render the same way given the same props, what is a simple performance optimization available for it?
options: Wrap it in the `React.memo` higher-order component.
answerText: Wrap it in the `React.memo` higher-order component.

question:
# Q3. How do you fix the syntax error that results from running this code?
```javascript
const person =(firstName, lastName) =>
{
  first: firstName,
  last: lastName
}
console.log(person("Jill", "Wilson"))

```
options: Call the function from another file.
Add a return statement before the first curly brace.
Replace the object with an array.

when you need to manage more complex state in an app

options: to change the layout of the screen

answerText: when you need the browser to paint before the effect runs

question:
# 20. What is the difference between the click behaviors of these two buttons (assuming that this.handleClick is bound correctly)?
```javascript
A. <button onClick={this.handleClick}>Click Me</button>
B. <button onClick={event => this.handleClick(event)}>Click Me</button>

```
options: Button A will not have access to the event object on click of the button.
Button B will not fire the handler this.handleClick successfully.
Button A will not fire the handler this.handleClick successfully.

question: # 22. When might you use `React.PureComponent`?
options: when you do not want your component to have props
when you have sibling components that need to be compared
when you want a default implementation of `shouldComponentUpdate()
when you do not want your component to have state
answerText: when you want a default implementation of `shouldComponentUpdate()

question: # 23. Why is it important to avoid copying the values of props into a component's state where possible?
options: because you should never mutate state
because `getDerivedStateFromProps()` is an unsafe method to use
because you want to allow a component to update in response to changes in the props
because you want to allow data to flow back up to the parent
answerText: because you want to allow a component to update in response to changes in the props

question: # 24. What is the children prop?
options: a property that adds child components to state
a property that lets you pass components as data to other components
a property that lets you set an array as a property
a property that lets you pass data to child elements
answerText: a property that lets you pass components as data to other components

options: to directly access the DOM node

answerText: to directly access the DOM node

question: # Q38. What is sent to an `Array.map()` function?
options: a callback function that is called once for each element in the array
the name of another array to iterate over
the number of times you want to call the function
a string describing what the function should do
answerText: a callback function that is called once for each element in the array

question: # Q39. Why is it a good idea to pass a function to `setState` instead of an object?
options: It makes sure that the object is not mutated.
setState` is asynchronous and might result in out of sync values.
answerText: setState` is asynchronous and might result in out of sync values.

```javascript
<button onClick={this.handleClick()}>Click this</button>

# Q48. Which answer best describes a function component?
options: A function component is the same as a class component.
A function component accepts a single props object and returns a React element.
A function component is the only way to create a component.
A function component is required to create a React component.
answerText: A function component accepts a single props object and returns a React element.

question: # Q49. Which library does the `fetch()` function come from?
options: - [X] No library. `fetch()` is supported by most browsers.
It will cause an error immediately.
It will execute the code inside the function, but only after waiting to ensure that no other component is accessing the name variable.
It will update the value of name once and not run again until name is changed from the outside.
It will cause an infinite loop.
answerText: It will update the value of name once and not run again until name is changed from the outside.

question: # Q51. Which choice will not cause a React component to rerender?
options: the value of one of the component's props changes
- [X] one of the component's siblings rerenders
